Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I stood in the middle of the living room, half-listening as my family debated where we should go this weekend. My little brother tugged at my sleeve, insisting I help him convince everyone to pick the amusement park. I knew they expected me to join in, to laugh and argue and be part of the plan. But my mind kept drifting back to the polling station earlier that day. I’d been waiting in line to vote, following every instruction, when an official announced that everyone with last names A–M should move to a new line. My last name started with “B,” so I hesitated, glancing at the new line, which was longer and slower. The official’s voice was firm, and I felt the pressure to comply, but I also wanted to get home quickly for family time. Now, as my family looked to me for input, I felt torn—caught between being the reliable sister they expected and the responsible voter who followed every rule. The weight of both roles pressed on me, and I could feel my frustration building, unsure which expectation I should meet.
